Award.AwardTitle: Rheology of the Lithospheric Mantle Beneath the Mojave Region from Naturally Deformed Peridotite Xenoliths
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this project is to characterize the rheological properties of a lithospheric mantle section using a suite of naturally deformed peridotite xenoliths erupted from the dominantly Pleistocene Cima volcanic field in the tectonically active Mojave desert of California. The part of the Mojave from which the Cima xenoliths are derived is a region in which several models of both the transient and steady-state rheology structure of the lithosphere have been made from surface velocity measurements following the Landers (1992) and Hector Mine (1999) earthquakes. It is also a region where geophysical observations (including seismic velocity and attenuation, and receiver function studies) highlight a drop in shear velocity that is rapid in depth, interpreted to be the seismological lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary; the magnitude of the shear velocity drop is too abrupt to be explained by temperature contrasts alone. The compositional and rheological properties of the mantle lithosphere here are therefore critical to understanding what influences both the large-wavelength post-seismic signal, and the abrupt transition from lithospheric lid to low viscosity, low velocity asthenospheric mantle. The study will document how stress, temperature, water content, deformation mechanism, lattice preferred orientation and style of localization vary with increasing depth (down to at least 45 km and as much as 70 km) in the lithospheric mantle from which the Cima xenoliths are derived. These natural measurements of rheological parameters will be used to a) test the applicability of experimentally derived flow laws and predictions of LPO development to mantle rocks, b) develop a naturally constrained stress profile of the upper mantle in the Mojave region and c) examine how the rheological parameters measured might influence a range of larger-scale geophysical models for the region. Some of the critical questions to be addressed include: is the mantle lithosphere beneath this region wet or dry? Does deformation in the mantle occur in narrow zones, or is it widely distributed? Is the mantle lithosphere the strongest ?load-bearing? part of the continental lithosphere, the weakest, or perhaps somewhere in between?

Results from this project will shed new light on how Earth?s rigid outer shell, the lithosphere, behaves in response to deformation along an active continental plate boundary. The PI and students will examine samples of the mantle section of the lithosphere entrained and brought to the surface by rapidly ascending magmas beneath young volcanoes. These entrained rocks, known as xenoliths, provide a unique perspective on the structure and physical properties of the lithosphere beneath some of the major earthquake-producing strike-slip faults in eastern California, including the faults that generated the Landers (1992, M=7.3) and Hector Mine (1999, M=7.1) earthquakes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mojave desert in southern California is an actively deforming region where lower crustal rocks and peridotites – the primary rock type in Earth’s mantle – have been brought to the surface as xenoliths through volcanic eruptions. By studying the physical and chemical properties of these xenoliths, we can gain direct insight into the nature of deformation (the process of physical change or distortion though applied pressure) occurring in the lithosphere of this complex region. The ultimate goal of this project was to characterize the rheology (the properties of materials that affect how they deform) of a lithospheric section using a suite of naturally deformed lower crustal and peridotite xenoliths erupted from two volcanic fields in the tectonically active Mojave region.

 

Through a wide array of analytical techniques applied to samples collected in the field, this project yielded several important outcomes. First, mantle peridotites from both localities studied preserve evidence for ductile, solid‐state deformation known as dislocation creep. The preservation of rocks showing varying degrees of deformation (from weakly deformed granular peridotites to highly deformed mylonitic peridotites) demonstrates that strain is localized in the mantle. This result supports the hypothesis that the brittle strike slip faults of the Eastern California Shear Zone seen at the surface extend into the mantle as areas of concentrated deformation known as ductile shear zones. Paleopiezometry (grain size analysis) of olivine indicated that stress magnitudes during deformation were very low: 12–26 MPa. This estimate, along with other measurements of various factors affecting rock strength and rheology, indicate that the mantle in this region is much weaker than the overlying crust. Calculations using olivine flow laws yield fast strain rates on the order of ∼10−12/s and an associated viscosity of ∼1019 Pa s, consistent with estimates of mantle lid viscosity from prior postseismic relaxation studies. The findings of this study provide improved constraints of the strength and physical properties of the earth’s lithosphere, which will directly inform future geophysical research concerned with earthquake cycle processes in this tectonically active region.

 

This regional study directly led to several other projects, including investigations into two other xenolith suites in the western US: those from the Navajo Volcanic field in the Four Corners region of the Colorado Plateau, and the Lunar Crater volcanic field in Central Nevada. Additionally, this award let to another project focused on understanding the factors that affect olivine crystallographic preferred orientation (CPO) development more broadly. Lithospheric mantle seismic anisotropy is produced primarily by CPO of deformed olivine, the most abundant mineral in the earth’s upper mantle. Because seismic anisotropy is one of the principal means of characterizing upper mantle flow directions, it is critical to understand how CPO is affected by deformation conditions, including temperature, pressure, water content, stress, and strain. A detailed study of naturally deformed peridotites from several localities, including the Mojave volcanic fields, revealed that deformation history and geometry play a most significant roles in CPO development than these factors at upper mantle conditions.

 

Because this work is interdisciplinary – connecting geochemistry, petrology, structural geology, rock deformation, geophysics, and seismology – it is of interest to researchers not only studying the Mojave lithosphere but also a wide range of problems in these subfields more generally. This research also has societal relevance as it provides important constraints on recent lithospheric deformation in a tectonically active region. In addition to these scientific broader impacts, this award funded two early career female scientists who are both members of underrepresented groups. These scientists (the PI and a PhD student) participated in many education and outreach initiatives including informal outreach through natural history museums, partnering with a local AP Environmental Science teacher to develop classroom activities, and organizing a departmental research symposium at The University of Austin at Texas.
